Compiled by Åšramaá¹‡a Chengguan of the Great Huayan Monastery on Mount Qingliang in the Tang Dynasty
The sixth section, There are ten buddha-realms, clarifies the gathering of the ocean-like assembly. Although the assembly is profound and vast,

it is difficult to fathom. In brief, ten approaches are opened: 1. The purpose of the gathering, 2. The causes of the gathering, 3. Distinguishing the types, 4. Determining the number, 5. Provisional and actual, 6. Spiritual stages, 7. Sequence, 8. Existence and non-existence, 9. Hearing and not hearing, 10. Explaining the text.
Now, the first.
Why have they come to where the Buddha is?
There are ten reasons:
First, it is for the sake of influence and companionship.
Second, it is for the sake of becoming assistants and attaining completeness, like the assembly that always follows Samantabhadra and others.
Third, it is for the sake of guarding the TathÄgata, like VajrapÄá¹‡i and others, who always diligently protect the places of the buddhas.
Fourth, it is for the sake of adornment, like the deities of the site of enlightenment, who always adorn and purify the palace of the buddhas.
Fifth, for making offerings, such as praising in verses is the offering of proper conduct, and flowers, banners, etc. are the offering of wealth.
Sixth, for initiating this sutra, those who request and debate are the reason for this.
Seventh, for hearing the Dharma and gaining benefits, the main audience comprehending is the category for this.
Eighth, for illustrating the Dharma, the leaders and forests illustrate faith, practice, etc., all having the same name.
And the bodhisattvas who emerge from the seat, etc., manifest the extraordinary. It also generally illustrates that myriad practices all lead to Buddhahood.
Ninth, for conforming with realization, Buddhas, bodhisattvas, etc. realize the teaching is not false.
Tenth, for revealing through contrast, i.e., the shravakas not hearing, revealing the Dharma is not shared.
For these many meanings, the ocean-like assembly gathers, not just for bearing witness and faith.
Second, the causes for gathering also have ten causes:

First, they had cultivated wholesome roots together with Vairocana TathÄgata in the past; second, they had been accepted by the Buddha's four means of gathering disciples; third, they had heard the perfect Dharma while in saá¹ƒsÄra; fourth, they had given rise to the great mind to protect all beings; fifth, they had made great vows to serve the Buddha in the past; sixth, they had followed the TathÄgata without ever being satisfied; seventh, they had never tired of hearing the true Dharma; eighth, they had been able to skillfully dispel the mind of arrogance; ninth, their bodies were pervaded by purified merit and wisdom; tenth, they had been born from the great ocean of wholesome roots of the same Dharma-nature.
For these many reasons, they were able to participate in this assembly.
Among them, the causes of gathering also include the general intention of gathering, as well as the specific causes of each group of beings, which can be understood by inference.
The third is distinguishing the types, which are formed from the above intention of gathering into ten categories:

First, the assembly of influence and reflection; second, the assembly of constant attendants; third, the assembly of guardians; fourth, the assembly of adornment and gathering; fifth, the assembly of offerings; sixth, the assembly of instigators; seventh, the assembly of those who are the main recipients of the teaching; eighth, the assembly that represents the Dharma; ninth, the assembly that bears witness to the Dharma; tenth, the assembly that manifests the Dharma.
It can be known according to the previous explanation.
Fourth, as for determining the number, how can one possibly count the assembly of the Dharma realm?
In terms of the text, the total number of assemblies in the nine gatherings is one hundred and seventy-five.
There are forty-one assemblies in the general introduction, namely, one assembly of the same birth, thirty-nine assemblies of different births, and one assembly on the lion seat.
If we also include the bodhisattvas flowing from the bodhi tree and the boundless bodhisattvas in the palace, there are a total of forty-three assemblies.
These forty-three assemblies are found throughout the nine gatherings:
The first gathering has two assemblies, namely, the newly gathered assembly from the ten directions and the assembly from between the Buddha's eyebrows, adding up to forty-five.
The second gathering has two new and old assemblies;
The third and fourth assemblies each have four types of assemblies, namely the new, old, Dharma-realization assembly, and celestial assembly;

The fifth assembly has 111 assemblies, namely the new and old assemblies. In the Ascending to the Heavens Chapter, there are 117 assemblies of offerings, as well as celestial assemblies and Dharma-realization assemblies;

The sixth assembly has four assemblies, namely the celestial assembly, the assembly of those born in the same realm, the assembly of those born in different realms, and the Dharma-realization assembly;
The seventh and eighth assemblies each have only one assembly, namely the old assembly of Samantabhadra and others;
The ninth assembly has three assemblies, namely the bodhisattva assembly, the Å›rÄvaka assembly, and the old assembly of celestial kings and others.
Although the old assembly is repeated, it is included in each assembly because it is different in each assembly.
However, these assemblies can be generally combined into one, because they are the assembly of the One Vehicle.
Or they can be divided into two, because there are real assemblies and transformed assemblies.
Or they can be divided into three, because they include humans, celestials, and spirits.
Or they can be divided into four, because they include buddhas, bodhisattvas, humans, and non-humans.
Or five, because humans are divided into heavenly and spiritual beings.
Or six, because animals are added.
Or seven, because heavenly beings are divided into desire and form realms.
Or eight, because bodhisattvas are divided into this world and other worlds.
Or nine, because other directions have masters and retinues.
Or ten, because Å›rÄvakas are added.
Or one hundred and seventy-five, as explained above.
Or immeasurable and boundless, because there are many categories of meaning and each one may be as numerous as the dust motes in a buddha land.
Moreover, like the newly assembled bodhisattvas and the multitudes emanating from their body hairs, all are the same as above, so each multitude is boundless.
This is still based on distinctions in appearance;

if they are fused and subsumed, each assembly contains one hundred and seventy-five multitudes, because in an assembly that accords with the interdependent origination of the Dharma realm, they are mutually present.
The above is based on one realm;

If we include the dust motes of the lands in the ten directions and different realms, like the endless and inexhaustible net of Indra, this is the number of the assembly in the ocean assembly of the Flower Ornament Sutra.
Fifth, as for provisional and real, those who can respond to the holy teachings and influence their traces are all provisional;
those who are the main audience are mostly real.

In the teachings that clarify the defiled lands, the various kinds of bodhisattvas and Å›rÄvakas are all both provisional and real. Those below the grounds are real, and those on the grounds are provisional, because the Dharma body is born in the five paths without being born.
The bodhisattvas in the pure lands are only real, because they are born in the reward of reality.
The various kinds of Å›rÄvakas are provisional.
The MahÄyÄna-samgraha says, In order to make the pure lands not empty, they transform into various kinds of assemblies.

If we rely on this sÅ«tra, the same birth and different birth are both provisional and real, because the real virtues of the ocean seal samÄdhi are included, because they manifest according to conditions and according to the stages, and because it says at the beginning of the second assembly, All are at the stage of one birth before Buddhahood.
When comparing the provisional and true of these ten categories, the assembly of responsive transformation has two categories:
First, the assembly of fruition virtues, which refers to those who can add and realize the Dharma.
The buddhas mutually serve as host and companion, neither provisional nor true;
If it is a bodhisattva of ultimate stage who responds to transformation, it is exclusively provisional.
There are sÅ«tras that say, In the past he was ÅšÄkyamuni's teacher, now he is a disciple of the Buddha.
The two Honored Ones do not simultaneously transform the world.
I am a bodhisattva and so forth, the assembly of those who receive the teaching is exclusively true, while the remaining eight are both provisional and true.
Regarding the sixth, the stages, some say:
All are stages of fruition, because they are manifested by the ocean seal of Vairocana.
Some say:
All are the ocean of causes and effects, which cannot be seen or heard.
The World-Honored One is also a cause, because he is manifested by consciousness.

Some say all are both causes and effects, because the fruition does not abandon the attainment, and the causes manifest according to type. Because the assembly of those who receive the teaching is correctly cultivating and progressing, the stage of causes assists the Buddha's transformation by the power of vows.
Or they are neither cause nor effect, because the great assembly of dependent origination is the true nature.
If we compare this with the previous provisional and true, then the fruition stage is exclusively provisional, while the causal stage is both provisional and true.

If we compare this with the previous ten categories, then the responsive and verifying Dharma are both cause and effect, while the other eight are only causes. The high and low of the causal stage are difficult to determine.
As for the seventh, the sequence, the bodhisattvas are listed first and the other assemblies are listed later, symbolizing the branching off from the root to form the branches.
The praise below clarifies the bodhisattvas first, symbolizing the returning to the root after seeking the branches.

This is because the root and branches are non-dual, so the two texts mutually bring them up.ğŸ”½Moreover, branching off from the root to form the branches must first be the lesser and then the greater, so the independent heavenly beings are the branches.
Returning the branches to the root must be from the profound to the shallow, so the independent heavenly beings are clarified first.
However, they all manifest the free and easy reversal and progression of the dependent origination of the Dharma realm.

Moreover, it illustrates the forty stages, each of which penetrates the gate of causes and encompasses the ocean of fruits, so they are mentioned alternately before and after, causing beings not to have the understanding of superiority and inferiority.
Eighth, as for existence and non-existence, there are also ten categories:
First, in terms of realms, there are no formless [realms];
Second, in terms of destinies, there are no hells, because these two are not vessels [for receiving the teaching].
If it is based on reincarnation, there are hellish celestial sons;
If it is based on those to be benefited, it also extends to the formless [realm], because all three realms are benefited.
Third, in terms of continents, only JambudvÄ«pa is listed, because the other three are omitted or because it would be difficult to accomplish [in them].
Fourth, in terms of vehicles, there are no two vehicles, because it is a teaching not shared [with the HÄ«nayÄna]. Below, in order to reveal the Dharma, they are also not seen or heard.

The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says: If it is a sÅ«tra of the HÄ«nayÄna, at the beginning only the Å›rÄvakas are listed. If it is a sÅ«tra of the MahÄyÄna, at the beginning both bodhisattvas and Å›rÄvakas are listed. If it is a sÅ«tra of the One Vehicle, at the beginning only bodhisattvas are listed.
Therefore, this sÅ«tra is referred to as a teaching not shared [with the HÄ«nayÄna].
Or, if a Mahayana sutra only lists the lesser ones, it is to attract them, like the Diamond Sutra;
Or, if it only lists the great, it also belongs to the Mahayana, because the host and companions are not complete;
Those with complete host and companions are necessarily the One Vehicle.
Fifth, regarding the assembly, there are no fourfold assemblies, because the lesser teachings have not yet been expounded.
Sixth, regarding the host, there is no human king, because the king does not yet know.
Seventh, regarding the three groups, there are no those of wrong determination, because they are obstructed and only benefit those born blind.
Eighth, regarding the inner and outer, there are no non-Buddhists, because they cannot fathom it.
Ninth, regarding the various heavens, there are no non-percipient beings, because they enter wrong determination.
Tenth, regarding good and evil, there are no evil maras, because they are not harmful and are included among the gods.
The above ten are spoken according to their characteristics.
In perfect interfusion, they all have and include everything.
Ninth, regarding hearing and not hearing, according to the provisional, they all hear each other before and after.
In terms of reality, they should meet and hear by themselves. Even if they do not arise in front and proceed to the back, they also do not know each other.
If it is about the sudden capacity, it is allowed to suddenly comprehend at one time.
The above nine gates are roughly explained like this, based on what is most apparent. In the medium and extensive versions, they may be hidden or apparent, so one should not be attached to the text.
The tenth is the explanation of the text.
In the first assembly, there are forty groups in total, which are divided into two parts:
The first is the same birth, and the rest are different births.
The treatise says, Vimukti candra is the same birth assembly.
It also says, The same birth assembly requests, so it can be known that it also includes those below the grounds. It is clear that it is not based on the stages.
Other explanations are not in accord with the meaning of the treatise.
What is meant by the same and different births?
However, there are two meanings:
First, it refers to various types, because they take on various forms of ordinary beings.
Bodhisattvas attain the dharma-nature body and take on the form of a single type of bodhisattva with humans.
Second, the two bodhisattvas are the same because they are common to all stages.
They are different because of the distinctions in the qualities of the Dharma realm.
As for the forty groups, the text all has three parts:
First, specifying the number and distinguishing the type; second, listing the names and concluding with a summary; third, encompassing the virtues and being all-encompassing.
Now, in the first group of those born together, in the first part that specifies the number and distinguishes the type, first it distinguishes the number;
Buddha-lands and below distinguishes the worlds, which can be roughly divided into three categories:
First, worlds; second, types; third, oceans.
Now, saying worlds means neither types nor oceans, which is commonly accepted by both provisional and real [teachings].
One trichiliocosm is the realm of transformation of one Buddha, therefore it is also called the Buddha land or Buddha realm, all according to this principle.
Dust motes refers to the quantity of seven atoms.

It means to grind the trichiliocosm into dust motes, with one mote representing one bodhisattva, then the number is already difficult to measure, let alone mentioning the number ten to represent infinity.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva distinguishes it from other assemblies.
The full name is Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, but here it is abbreviated.
However, there are three explanations:

First, bodhi is the Buddha-fruit to be sought, and sattva is the sentient beings to be transformed, which are the objects of compassion and wisdom. It is named bodhisattva because it is named after the object.
Second, bodhi is the fruit to be sought, and sattva is the person who seeks it. It is named bodhisattva because it combines the able and the object.
Third, sattva means courageous and valiant. It is called bodhisattva because one courageously seeks great enlightenment.
MahÄ means great. Greatness has four meanings:
First, the vow is great, because one seeks great enlightenment;
Second, the practice is great, because the two benefits are accomplished;
Third, the time is great, because it takes three incalculably long eons;
Fourth, the virtue is great, because it is endowed with the merits of the One Vehicle.
The first two are common to those below the grounds, while the latter two may only be on the grounds. There are also other great ones, but they do not go beyond these.
These are all the inner retinue of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, always following him in motion and stillness, so it says surrounded by them.
Second, Their names and below lists the names and concludes with the number. First it lists their names, then it concludes by showing that it is abbreviated.

Now, the sage has no name, but is given a name for the sake of things. Although the names differ a thousand times, many are based on practice and virtue. All practices and virtues are complete, but they are separately designated according to the occasion. The first ten have the same name Pervasive to show that they possess the virtues of the general characteristics of the Dharma realm;
The latter ten have different names to show that they possess the virtues of the specific characteristics of the Dharma realm.
The general and specific characteristics are fused as one Dharma realm.

Now, the Pervasive in the first ten names is the general of the specific. The ten differences below Pervasive show that it can be specific while still pervasive, and only then does the meaning of pervasiveness become complete.

This is the practice of Samantabhadra that all buddhas of the past and present have practiced together. It follows the distinctions of the various stages and is not the same. Even if one attains perfect enlightenment, it still includes universal practice, so it is explained first.
As for Samantabhadra, the essence is all-pervading, called universal, and the virtues formed by following conditions are called virtuous. This is based on the intrinsic nature.
Moreover, to comprehensively benefit without remainder is called universal, and to be close to the ultimate sage is called virtuous. This is based on the various stages of Samantabhadra.
Moreover, to have virtues that pervade the Dharma realm is called universal, and to be supremely harmonious and good is called virtuous. This is based on the corresponding stage of Samantabhadra.
Moreover, to have no end to the fruits is called universal, and to not abandon the gate of causes is called virtuous. This is based on the Samantabhadra after Buddhahood.

In the stages, Samantabhadra's compassion and wisdom are both in operation. After Buddhahood, Samantabhadra's ocean of wisdom is already full, and the operation is the compassion within wisdom, quiescent yet always used to the end of the future.
Moreover, one is all, called universal, and all is one, called virtuous. This is based on merging and subsuming.

The reason for listing it first is that it is the leader, the master of the Dharma gate, the essence of the Dharma realm, all bodhisattvas do not go beyond it, not a single tathÄgata is not accomplished through it, and it causes those who hear it to see the nature of the tathÄgata-garbha within themselves and practice universal practice.
Although above there are many meanings of separate explanation, now it is combined explanation according to the specific name.
Being virtuous everywhere is called universal virtue, which is the universality of the essence.
This one is the general, and the other nine are the specific.
Second, virtue is universal, referring to the virtue that accords with the nature and fills the Dharma realm, which is the most supreme. It illuminates without exception, like the light of a lamp.
Third, wisdom is universal, illuminating and illuminating the adorned lands, decisively standing out.
Fourth, practice is universal, the inner practice is perfectly pure, and the flame of wisdom externally illuminates, thus called wonderful.
Fifth, sound is universal, possessing all sounds, expounding the practice of the Buddha's pure land that is profound, vast, and lofty.
Sixth, wisdom is universal, illuminating the inexhaustible realm of the Buddha's Dharma realm.
Seventh, the mind is universal, with the adornment of the wisdom jewel on the crown of the head, as the path of practice and so forth are like flowers that rise above the world.
Eighth, awareness is universal, fully aware of nature and characteristics, and all sounds delight the faculties, thus there is none who does not return.
Ninth, blessings are universal, with no hindrances that are not purified, as they accord with the truth and are inexhaustible.
Tenth, characteristics are universal, with no characteristics of light as light, universally benefiting sentient beings, thus the six characteristics are harmoniously integrated, contemplate this.
Second, the ten different names of bodhisattvas below sea and moon.

First, the great bright one of the sea and moon light, the ten virtues and ten mountains all rely on the great ocean, the ten grounds and ten perfections all rely on the Buddha's wisdom. Looking at the moon in the ocean is pure and deep, relying on wisdom to adorn the realm is deep and pure. Like the ocean is great, like the moon is bright, thus it is named.
Second, the sound of the Dharma is like thunder, thus it is called cloud sound. Eloquence is like the light of the ocean.
Moreover, above the ocean there is light, with no end to the horizon. The Buddha's wisdom gives rise to function, and in a single thought it is universally pervasive.
Purifying afflictions without end is called the treasury of no-defilements.
Third, cultivating and perfecting the two adornments is like a pure jewel, secret and lofty, thus the phrase crown is used.
Fourth, the Dharma King appears, with sovereign function, the two adornments complete, as the light of merit.
Fifth, fearlessly transforming beings without being tainted by transformation, raining the profound and wondrous Dharma like unravelling the crown jewel.
Sixth, the cloud of compassion and the sun of wisdom mutually assist and illuminate each other, universally responding for a long eon, towering like a banner.
Seventh, firm and sharp wisdom together with vigor, thus it is called great wisdom as the basis of practice, or equanimity as the cause of longevity.
Eighth, the practice of precepts and so forth gives rise to fragrant flames, and the lofty and straight wisdom of various kinds is called the banner of light.
Ninth, the universal illumination of the light of wisdom is the virtue of great illumination, and adapting to beings according to reality is called the deep and beautiful sound.
Tenth, the light of great wisdom universally illuminates the Buddha's realm, causing merit and non-merit to be mutually meritorious, also called great.
Second, such and so forth concludes the brief and reveals the extensive.
The third, from These bodhisattvas, is the perfection of virtues. There are two parts: first, praising their excellent virtues, and second, concluding with many aspects.
In the first, there are also two:
The first two sentences praise based on conditions, the rest praise based on practice.
Now, the first.
The first sentence is the same practice as the past causes, showing that the host and companions have a basis.
The latter sentence is born from the ocean of virtues, clarifying that the birth is for the sake of the retinue.
As for Vairocana, Vairo means universal, and cana means light.
Returning to the Chinese language, it should be said universal illumination.
However, there are two meanings:

First, the light of the body universally illuminates to the end of space and even the dust motes, and second, the light of wisdom universally illuminates the true and conventional, the layers upon layers of the Dharma realm.
The body and wisdom are combined into one body, the perfect brightness shines alone, and the virtues are boundless, thus establishing this name.
Moreover, vi means various, loka means obstruction, and na means exhaustion and entering, which means various obstructions are exhausted and various virtues are perfected.
Therefore, the Samantabhadra Contemplation Sutra says, Shakyamuni is called Vairocana, pervading everywhere, which means the body is also pervasive, not only the light is pervasive.
It also says, The place where the Buddha resides is called the eternally quiescent light, which means the land is also light.
It also says, The place accomplished by the perfection of permanence, the place established by the perfection of self, which means the meaning of perfect virtues.
It also says, The place where the perfection of purity eliminates the characteristics of existence, which means the meaning of exhausted obstructions.

It also says, The place where the perfection of bliss does not abide in the characteristics of body and mind, the place where one does not see the characteristics of all dharmas that exist or not, which means the meaning of realization and entry.

It also says, Like quiescence, liberation, up to the perfection of wisdom, this is the Dharma of the permanence of form, clarifying that they are all responsive and true, and are the original teacher.
The text of this sutra will be discussed in the chapter on the original meaning.
As for the phrase gathering of wholesome roots, it refers to being fully equipped with the provisions for the Way.
As for the phrase cultivating the practice of bodhisattvas, it refers to doing what should be done.
How is it that they gather together?
Because they are mutually the principal and the companions.
There are three kinds of principal and companions:

1. The principal and companions of dedication, 2. The principal and companions of practicing together, 3. The principal and companions of being in accord with the characteristics, all of which are called gathering together.

As for the phrase born from the ocean of wholesome roots in the latter phrase, it means that the Buddha's virtues are boundless, and the accumulation of wondrous Dharma treasures and wisdom and concentration are abundant, therefore it is called an ocean.
There are four from which it is born:
1. Born from the ocean of one's own wholesome roots, because the ten bodies have already been perfected.

2. Born from the ocean of the original teacher, because the Buddha is the supreme condition, has already embraced and accepted one, and has bestowed the Dharma, enabling one's practice to be perfected.
3. Born together with Vairocana in the ocean of other Buddhas, because it is said above that they gather together.

Fourth, they are born from the ocean of the Buddha's nature, because the virtues of the Buddhas are the same, of a single flavor, and one simply cultivates according to one's nature, which is being born. Because it does not distinguish self and other.
The Sanskrit version says: Born from the same ocean of wholesome roots as the Buddhas.
Second, below the perfections, it praises based on the virtues of practice.

A great person must revere virtue, broaden their work, empty their mind, and transcend the body. Because they revere virtue, they progress to equal the fruition of the Buddhas. Because their work is broad, their practice extends throughout the Dharma realm. Because their mind is empty, their wisdom encompasses myriad dharmas without being hindered. Because they transcend the body, their merit flows to the end of time without ceasing. Therefore, their virtue is difficult to name.
It is roughly divided into three parts:
First, the virtues of self-benefit and causal practices; second, the virtues of advanced fruition practices; third, the virtues of the non-obstruction of the two practices.
In the beginning, there are also three parts:
First, the perfection of self-beneficial practices; second, the fulfillment of benefiting others; third, the ultimate stage of realizing the truth.
Now, there are three sentences at the beginning:

First, the perfection of the practices of the perfections, referring to the six perfections, ten perfections, and eighty-four thousand, accumulated over many eons, thoroughly understanding principles and phenomena, thus called perfection.
Second, below eye of wisdom, the ten eyes are clear and penetrating, discernment is called wisdom, illuminating is called eyes.
Obstructions and illnesses are completely eliminated, and there is no knowledge that does not illuminate, thus called clear and penetrating.
Among the five eyes, the eye of wisdom observes principles, and principles have no different flavors, thus called equal observation;
Among the ten eyes, the eye of wisdom observes phenomena, and phenomena are all seen, thus called equal observation.
This means thoroughly seeing its phenomena as clear, and deeply understanding its nature as penetrating.
Wishing to include all in one eye, being all-encompassing in phenomena and principles, only the eye of wisdom is mentioned.
Third, below in all, the profound samÄdhi is already perfected.
SamÄdhi means equally holding, far away from sinking and floating, equally holding the mind towards one object.

And saying various means that the remaining conditions are also one-pointed, so the samÄdhi of suchness is its essence of concentration. Following the objects, it enters the many branches, so it says various.
Horizontally, it is without fixed limits; vertically, it penetrates deeply without end. Therefore, it says complete.
The obstacles to concentration are forever gone, so it says pure.
Second, below eloquence, the fulfillment of benefiting others has three phrases, which are the three wheels of transformation and benefit.
One word contains the four forms of eloquence, which is the wheel of right teaching.
Eloquence means skillfully revealing the profound principles, and talent means skillfully responding to the capacities of the audience.
When myriad dharmas are all expounded, it is vast and boundless. When a thousand difficulties are responded to differently, it is inexhaustible. Therefore, it is like the ocean.
Moreover, when the ocean encounters wind conditions, great waves surge like clouds. When wisdom encounters requests from the audience, verbal eloquence rises like waves.
Since requests are allowed, the boundless eloquence is also vast and inexhaustible.
Second, below endowed with the Buddha, the wheel of spiritual powers of the body.
It means the three karmas are faultless, wisdom is profound and unperturbed, and in order to possess the Buddha's merits, one attains the external demeanor of solemnity and awe-inspiring respect.
Third, below knowing sentient beings, is the mental activity of the wheel of recording the mind.
The meaning of faculties is generally explained, and the text contains nature and desires.
As for according to, faculties have maturity, and transformation does not miss the time;
Vessels have large and small, and the Dharma is bestowed without error.
Transformation refers to teaching and transforming, which is to accept those who should be accepted.
Subjugation refers to taming, which is to subdue those who should be subdued.
By fully practicing this, one enters the true Dharma.
Third, below entering the treasury of the Dharma realm, is the ultimate stage of realizing the principle, which also has three phrases.
First, the Dharma of realizing the principle, which means using great wisdom to realize and enter the treasury of the equal true Dharma realm.
According to the Buddha Nature Treatise, there are five treasuries:
First, the tathÄgata-garbha, which means being in the entanglements, because it contains the dharmas of fruition.
Second, the intrinsically pure treasury, which refers to being entangled yet unstained.
Third, the treasury of the Dharma body, which refers to the fruition stage, being the basis for merits and virtues.
Fourth, the supreme treasury beyond the world, which refers to being free from entanglements and surpassing the two vehicles and bodhisattvas.
Fifth, the treasury of the Dharma realm, which refers to both the cause and fruition, externally upholding all defiled and pure conditioned phenomena, thus called the Dharma realm;
internally containing all the inherent merits and virtues of the Ganges sands, it is therefore also called a treasury.
This meaning is broad and inclusive, thus it is now realized and entered.

As for the non-differentiation of wisdom, the treasury that is realized is equal, and it is necessary to be without discrimination in order to accord with it. This then means that wisdom itself is without differentiation, which is precisely due to the above meaning of the non-distinction between subject and object.

Moreover, this wisdom that is able to realize merges with the treasury that is realized, becoming a single flavor, without the distinction between object and subject. Therefore, it is said to be without differentiation.
This is further twofold:
First, because of being the same without characteristics.
The following passage in the sutra states: There is not a single dharma that is entered by cognition, nor is there a single cognition that enters into dharmas.
Second, because they are the same as the dharma realm, subject and object each completely include the other.
The following passage states: There is no suchness outside of cognition that is entered by cognition, because cognition completely includes suchness.
There is also no cognition outside of suchness that can realize suchness, because suchness completely includes cognition.
If they are all of one flavor, how can it be that cognition is the same as the object and there is no cognition?
Ancient masters explain:
Because the characteristics of cognition are exhausted, it is not existent. In order to cause the characteristics of cognition to be exhausted, it is not nonexistent.

If it were not so, how could it be that all characteristics are exhausted and cognition alone remains?ğŸ”½Therefore, with regard to objects, it does not obstruct the true while always being conventional; with regard to cognition, it does not obstruct quiescence while always illuminating. Objects and cognition are not the same.
Objects do not obstruct the conventional while always being true; cognition does not abandon illumination while always being quiescent. Objects and cognition are not different.
The object is empty and existent, non-dual, and the cognition is the unity of quiescence and illumination. Therefore, it is said to be without distinction.
The above explanation is based on the quiescence of true reality, which accords with the quiescence of cessation;
The flowing and moving of conventional reality accords with the illumination of contemplation.

In the Awakening of Faith and other texts, this explanation is given, but it does not exhaust the source, because the illumination of true reality cannot be called illumination, and when illuminating the conventional, it cannot be immediately quiescent.
The correct explanation now is: When speaking of function, it is the same yet different, because the object cannot illuminate and cognition has illumination;
When speaking of quiescence, it is different yet the same, because the object and cognition have no different flavor.
Because they are the same, there is no mind of self and other, because forgetting the mind accords with reality;
Because they are different, the function of illumination is not lost, because cognition is different from wood and stone.
Therefore, it is called true cognition realizing reality. The object is only quiescent, and cognition is quiescent yet always illuminating.
If it is about illuminating the conventional, then it is the subsequently attained cognition illuminating the differentiated object;

If it is about the fusion of the true and the conventional, the realm is the non-duality of the true and conventional, and the wisdom is the simultaneous practice of the expedient and real, also being of one taste without losing stillness, because although there is simultaneous practice, it is immediately quiescent.
